pay.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: to give someone money for something you buy or for a service
pay.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: How would you like to pay?
You’d get a discount for paying cash.
Can I pay by credit card?
He wanted to be paid in dollars.
Mum paid for my driving lessons.
He didn’t even offer to pay me for the ticket.
Ray paid some kids to wash the car.
I paid him $5 to cut the grass.
pay.translation[0].definitions[0].note_b: You pay an amount or you pay a person
You pay for something that you buy
You pay an amount or a person for something that you buy
She paid me for the drinks

You pay by a particular method
You can pay by credit card
pay.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: to pay money that you owe to a person, company etc
pay.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: I forgot to pay the gas bill!
You pay tax at the basic rate.
Is it okay if I pay you what I owe you next week?
pay.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: to give someone money for the job they do
pay.translation[0].definitions[2].note.t: paid holiday/leave (=time when you are not working but are still paid)
pay.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: How much do they pay you?
Some lawyers get paid over $400 an hour.
They’re only paid about £4 an hour.
pay somebody $100 a day/£200 a week etc
We get paid weekly on Fridays.
Many of the workers are very badly paid.
pay.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: to give money to someone because you are ordered to by a court as part of a legal case
pay.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: She had to pay a £35 fine for speeding.
Martins was ordered to pay court costs of £1,500.
The company were forced to pay £5,000 in compensation.
pay.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: to say something good or polite about or to someone
pay.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: The minister paid tribute to the work of the emergency services.
I came by to pay my respects (=visit or send a polite greeting to someone) to Mrs Owens.
I was just trying to pay her a compliment.
pay.translation[0].definitions[5].defini: if a particular action pays, it brings a good result or advantage for you
pay.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: It pays to get some professional advice before you make a decision.
It would pay you to ask if there are any jobs going at the London office.
Getting some qualifications now will pay dividends (=bring a lot of advantages) in the long term.
pay.translation[0].definitions[6].defini: if a shop or business pays, it makes a profit
pay.translation[0].definitions[6].exampl: If the pub doesn’t start to pay, we’ll have to sell it.
The farm just manages to pay its way (=make as much profit as it costs to run).
pay.translation[0].definitions[7].defini: to suffer or be punished for something you have done wrong
pay.translation[0].definitions[7].exampl: They paid dearly for their mistakes.

pay.translation[0].note_box[2].sections[: pay
to give someone money for something you are buying from them, or a service they are providing
I paid a lot of money for that computer.
You have to pay to park your car.
meet the cost of something
to pay for something for someone else, or to provide the money needed to do something
We will meet the cost of your travelling expenses.
The cost will be met from public donations.
foot the bill
to pay for something for someone else, especially when you do not want to, or do not think that you should
As usual, the taxpayer will have to foot the bill.
pick up the tab
to pay for something
My company will pick up the tab for all moving costs.
fork out/shell out
to pay a lot of money for something because you have to and not because you want to
He had to fork out £500 to get his car fixed.
Fans are having to shell out roughly $65 per seat for football games.
settle the bill
to pay the bill after eating a meal, staying in a hotel etc
She went down to the hotel lobby to settle the bill.
to pay a particular amount of money for something – used especially when saying how much you are willing to pay
How much will you give me for the car?
I’ll give you $50 for the lot  (=for everything).
something is on somebody
used when saying that someone else will pay for your meal, drinks etc
Order whatever you like – this is on me!
The drinks are on the house (=the bar, restaurant etc will let you have them for free).
Put your money away – the drinks are on us.
